markups.originaltext: Effectiveness can be learned—and it also has to belearned.

textblocks.text:
Effectiveness can be learned—and it also has to be
learned.

markups.originaltext: To be effective is the job of the executive.

textblocks.text: To be effective is the job of the executive.

markups.originaltext: Intelligence, imagination, and knowledge are essentialresources, but only effectiveness converts them into results.

textblocks.text:
Intelligence, imagination, and knowledge are essential
resources, but only effectiveness converts them into results.

markups.originaltext: The knowledge worker cannot be supervised closely or indetail. He can only be helped. But he must direct himself, and hemust direct himself toward performance and contribution, thatis, toward effectiveness.

textblocks.text:
The knowledge worker cannot be supervised closely or in
detail. He can only be helped. But he must direct himself, and he
must direct himself toward performance and contribution, that
is, toward effectiveness.

markups.originaltext:
The greatest wisdom not applied to action and behavior
is meaningless data.

textblocks.text: The greatest wisdom not applied to action and behavior

markups.originaltext: Every knowledge worker in modern organization is an “exec-utive”

textblocks.text:
Every knowledge worker in modern organization is an “exec-
utive”

markups.originaltext: Most managers are executives—though not all.

textblocks.text: Most managers are executives—though not all.

markups.originaltext: Knowledge work is not defined by quantity. Neither isknowledge work defined by its costs. Knowledge work is definedby its results.

textblocks.text:
Knowledge work is not defined by quantity. Neither is
knowledge work defined by its costs. Knowledge work is defined
by its results.

markups.originaltext: 1. The executive’s time tends to belong to everybody else.

textblocks.text: 1. The executive’s time tends to belong to everybody else.

markups.originaltext: The fundamental problem is the reality around the execu-tive. Unless he changes it by deliberate action, the flow of eventswill determine what he is concerned with and what he does.

textblocks.text:
The fundamental problem is the reality around the execu-
tive. Unless he changes it by deliberate action, the flow of events
will determine what he is concerned with and what he does.

markups.originaltext: If the executive lets the flow of events determine what hedoes, what he works on, and what he takes seriously, he willfritter himself away “operating.”

textblocks.text:
If the executive lets the flow of events determine what he
does, what he works on, and what he takes seriously, he will
fritter himself away “operating.”

markups.originaltext: What the executive needs are criteria which enable him towork on the truly important, that is, on contributions andresults, even though the criteria are not found in the flow ofevents.

textblocks.text:
What the executive needs are criteria which enable him to
work on the truly important, that is, on contributions and
results, even though the criteria are not found in the flow of
events.

markups.originaltext: 2. Executives are forced to keep on “operating” unless theytake positive action to change the reality in which they live andwork.

textblocks.text:
2. Executives are forced to keep on “operating” unless they
take positive action to change the reality in which they live and
work.

markups.originaltext: 3. The third reality pushing the executive toward ineffective-ness is that he is within an organization. This means that he iseffective only if and when other people make use of what he con-tributes.

textblocks.text:
3. The third reality pushing the executive toward ineffective-
ness is that he is within an organization. This means that he is
effective only if and when other people make use of what he con-
tributes.

title: The Effective Executive The Definitive Guide to Getting the Right Things Done (Peter F. Drucker)
